I. INTRODUCTION
1. The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will carry out cross-sectoral and
thematic regional studies on the widening “protection gap” (the gap between the amount of
insurance and/or pension coverage that is economically beneficial and what is purchased), and
how the development of insurance and pension markets in developing member countries (DMCs)
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) can help in closing this gap. The focus will be on creating
an enabling environment for structuring innovative risk financing solutions to help meet emerging
challenges in the face of growing inequality, demographic change, and increasing climate change
and disaster-risk exposures. Cross-country comparisons will help identify areas where insurance
can  help  catalyze  long-term  funding,  expand  financial  inclusion,  improve  the  reliability  of
retirement income for the disabled and the elderly, and increase financial resilience.
2. The TA is included in the ADB Management-approved 2019 results-based work plan of
the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC).1 It aims to address the
following operational priority areas as outlined in ADB’s Strategy 2030: (i) addressing remaining
poverty and reducing inequalities by strengthening social protection; (ii) accelerating progress in
gender  equality  by  recommending  insurance  and  pensions  products  targeting  women  and
businesses owned by women; (iii) promoting rural development and food security, including agro-
businesses and micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs), and tackling the adverse
effects  of  climate  change  and  natural  hazards  through  innovative  insurance  solutions;  (iv)
strengthening governance and institutional capacity to further develop the insurance markets by
ensuring  the  observance  of  international  financial  standards;  and  (v)  fostering  regional
cooperation and integration by promoting regional risk financing initiatives.2
II. ISSUES
3. Insufficient access to risk transfer and risk-sharing solutions. Insurance is well-
recognized in the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development as a financial tool
that  needs  to  be  actively  used to  attain  the  agreed  outcomes  outlined  in the  Sustainable
Development  Goals,3 the  Paris  Agreement,  and  the  Sendai  Framework  for  Disaster  Risk
Reduction. Comprehensive risk management includes the integration of insurance and pension
instruments for sustainable development, and the private insurance and pension markets can play
a critical role in supporting the real economy by delivering risk financing and protection solutions.
The insurance and pension industry will serve an increasingly critical role in protecting households
and businesses against a widening range of risks, heightening the importance of observing the
principles and standards of the International Association of Insurance Supervisors.
4. Insufficient risk resilience by micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises; farmers;
and households. The assets, lives, and incomes of MSMEs, farmers, and households are
disproportionately exposed to natural hazards and man-made perils, which are increasing in
frequency and severity, and in addition further exacerbated by climate change. These disasters
result in financial losses and loss of livelihoods with devastating impact on development. In
emerging Asia, the insurance protection gap exceeds 90% for three major perils—storms, floods
and earthquakes—which can have a significant economic burden through loss and damage to
infrastructure and property, and loss of income and livelihoods. Insurance and mutual insurance
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 3 October 2019. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
3  United Nations. 2015. 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development Goals. New York.

2 
can offer financial, operational, and information benefits to the insured population, such as 
guaranteed access to funds up to agreed limits, planning certainty through the payment of 
premiums, no payback obligation as opposed to lending-based solutions, fast payout under 
parametric schemes, and improved economic efficiency of resource allocation as a result of 
pricing of risks through insurance. 
5. Widening pension gap results in reduced retirement living standards. Pensions are
generally viewed as a type of social insurance provided through a public mechanism, because
private pensions are very limited in many countries. Changes in the old-age dependency ratio
(which measures the number of elderly people as a share of those of working age) challenges
most public pension systems in Asia and the Pacific. With available pension fund assets becoming
insufficient to meet the obligations promised to current and future retirees, governments and
employers are increasingly shifting longevity and market or savings risks to individuals, e.g.,
through  reduced  public  pension  schemes  and  transition  from  defined-benefit  to  defined-
contribution schemes  in  retirement  plans.  This  trend  is  further  increasing  gaps  in  pension
protection and can impose a severe additional financial burden on society and will most likely
increase the number of individuals who outlive their assets and are at risk of falling into poverty.
Publicly mandated pension schemes need to be complemented with occupational and individual
voluntary pension schemes to ensure future retirement income is adequate, particularly for the
informal sector and people with disabilities. Some pension schemes are privately managed by
insurance companies, which assume the longevity risks from individuals who seek steady, reliable
retirement income.
6. Innovative solutions to reduce the protection gap. When considering innovative ways
to increase insurance and pension coverage governments, communities, and financial institutions
(including banking, securities, and insurance institutions) all have a role to play in creating
sufficiently large risk communities. Governments can assist by providing an enabling policy and
regulatory environment; introducing compulsory insurance schemes to increase take-up rates by
forming the widest possible risk community, and eliminating adverse selection; or encouraging
the establishment of intra-community support mechanisms—such as cooperatives, mutual and
insurance pools for MSMEs, farmers, and grassroots organizations—to mitigate the economic
impact of shocks. Increased protection for the population at risk can be provided by combining
elements of risk retention in the form of household savings, risk-sharing by way of developing
community reserves with contributions from households, and risk transfer via insurance. Digital
and mobile distribution and the use of new technology can leapfrog access to insurance in
countries with few insurance intermediaries and poorly developed distribution frameworks.
7. The TA will draw on lessons from previous TA projects on insurance, which include the
importance  of  (i) developing  cross-sectoral  and  thematic  synergies  (e.g.,  social  protection,
agriculture,  and  rural  development)  to  support  the  expansion  of  ADB’s  insurance  market
operations; (ii) engaging in dialogue with DMCs to promote market-led innovative insurance
products and schemes; and (iii) developing an enabling policy and regulatory landscape in which
insurance  can  scale.4 Insurance  supervisors  play  a  critical  role  in  creating  the  enabling
environment that incentivizes insurers to design innovative products and schemes. The TA will
leverage existing partnerships with international standard-setting bodies (SSBs) to ensure that
4  ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance for Establishing Sound Microinsurance Markets in Asia and the Pacific. Manila; 
and ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance for Thematic Self-Assessment and Peer Review of International Association 
of Insurance Supervisors Insurance Core Principles and Standards for Asia and the Pacific (Phase 1). Manila.

3 
the development of the insurance markets align with international financial standards.5 The TA 
will look into existing risk-financing arrangements under consideration, such as those under the 
Asia–Pacific  Climate  Finance  Fund,6 and  support  the  development  and  implementation  of 
pipeline projects for ADB’s operations departments. 
III. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A. Impact and Outcome
8. The TA is aligned with the following impact: enabling environment for incentivizing the
participation of insurers and reinsurers improved (footnote 2). The TA will have the following
outcome: innovative insurance solutions expanded.7
B. Outputs, Methods, and Activities
9. Output 1: Analytical studies on insurance and pensions solutions delivered. The TA
will produce at least three regional analytical studies on (i) insurance solutions that can make
access to finance more efficient for businesses owned by women and MSMEs (e.g., linking credit
with insurance; and providing complete financial protection, such as crop insurance to mitigate
farmers’ risks, portfolio insurance, and regional risk-sharing arrangements);8 (ii) risk financing
instruments that can make funding more effective by linking funding to results and by using
technology (e.g., to enable forecast-based insurance, parametric insurance, and microinsurance
to support high-impact government programs); and (iii) individually funded and privately managed
pension products and schemes for the disabled, elderly and women, that take into consideration
the impact of both the corporate and personal income tax regimes, to ensure adequate, steady
and reliable retirement incomes (e.g., through occupational and individual voluntary pensions,
and reverse mortgages). The country selection process for output 1 will (i) target DMCs interested
in carrying out reforms by involving the private sector to bridge the protection gap; and (ii) consider
DMCs’ gross national income, insurance penetration, regulatory frameworks, general readiness,
possible impacts, and the state of technological infrastructure to enable savings.9 The regional
analytical studies will also look at experience in countries outside Asia and the Pacific, with results
published online and disseminated in regional seminars.
10. Output 2: Use of new technology for developing innovative insurance solutions
demonstrated. The TA will pilot one project in a DMC where there is an ongoing finance sector
project.10 It will involve the use of innovative technology for faster processing of loan applications
and disbursement of loans, e.g., leveraging financial technology to help banks and insurers better
assess risk and link insurance with credit to improve access to finance for MSMEs and agro-
businesses. A feasibility study that includes a comprehensive analysis of the rural and agriculture
credit and insurance ecosystem will inform the design of the pilot. The study will assist ADB’s
operations departments to demonstrate that impact and policy recommendations from the pilot

will help in identifying opportunities for expansion and replication in an enabling legal and 
regulatory environment. The pilot will provide opportunities to develop an operations project 
pipeline through investments in insurance and reinsurance vehicles and new technology. Briefs, 
interviews,  and  video  blogs  will  be  developed  in  conjunction  with  ADB’s  Department  of 
Communications to capture and showcase the impact of the pilot project, including any lessons. 
11. Output 3: Capacity of national and regional policymakers, insurance supervisors,
and other insurance industry stakeholders improved. The results of the analytical studies and
pilot project will be used to (i) provide an overview of the depth and breadth of the insurance and
capital markets, including the presence of pension funds and mutual funds; and (ii) make
recommendations regarding financial instruments and schemes (including alternative risk transfer
and risk sharing) for replication and expansion. Savings and the purchase of insurance will be
encouraged through the development of an enabling environment by means of knowledge support
and  capacity-building  events  for  policymakers,  financial  market  supervisors,  and  insurance
industry stakeholders in collaboration with international (re)insurers and international financial
SSBs, which will serve to strengthen institutional capacity, including by promoting understanding
of financial products for target markets.
C. Cost and Financing
12. The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant
basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Special Fund (FSDPSF),11 and (ii)
$500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge
Partnership Fund (EAKPF) and administered by ADB. The cost estimates and financing plan are
in Appendix 2.
13. Eligible  and  non-eligible  expenditures.  Eligible  FSDPSF  expenditures  include
consulting services, capacity building, advisory services, designing new financing instruments,
pilot  tests,  small  equipment  and  systems  procurement,  and  support  for  regional  financial
cooperation among DMCs. Vehicle purchases and salaries for civil servants are non-eligible
expenditures.
14. EAKPF will finance operational expenses related to eligible proposals agreed upon by the
Government of the Republic of Korea and ADB. It will not be used for (i) civil works, (ii)
procurement of large-scale equipment, (iii) permanent staffing costs, or (iv) the hiring of staff
consultants.
D. Implementation Arrangements
15. ADB will administer the TA. The Finance Sector Group under the Sector Advisory Service
Cluster,  SDCC  will  implement  the  TA  and  carry  out  TA  administration  and  supervision,
implementation oversight, and communication with consultants and stakeholders in coordination
with the relevant sector and thematic groups, and operations departments. Activities organized
under the TA will include organization of and participation in knowledge events such as workshops,
conferences, and seminars to be conducted in close collaboration with relevant operations
departments and sector and thematic groups. ADB staff involved with the TA may participate as
resource persons in knowledge-sharing events, which will also include eliciting feedback and
suggestions on improving the activities being implemented under the TA. A budget will be
allocated for ADB staff to provide support services (travel and related costs for secretarial and

16. Consulting  services.  The  TA  will  require  6  person-months  of  services  from  an
international  consulting  firm.  Individual  consultants  will  be  recruited  through  framework
agreements or individual selection to provide 11 person-months of international and 16 person-
months of national consultant services. The TA will also require a total of 2 person-months of
services by resource persons. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions
and/or staff instructions. Output-based or lumpsum contracts will be considered for consulting
services where appropriate with the concurrence of ADB’s Procurement, Portfolio and Financial
Management Department.12
17. Pilot testing of project approach. Consultants shall be engaged to carry out a feasibility
study to identify a technology platform to be created or adapted in the local context in consultation
with stakeholders. They will also identify suitable financial technology business applications for
credit scoring, customer profiling of MSMEs and farmers for onboarding by lending institutions,
risk modelling for insurance underwriting and claims administration, and using digital distribution
channels. Application developers will then be selected to design (in conjunction with financial
regulators, lending institutions, and insurers) customized applications to enable a bundled suite
of automated credit and insurance services to be offered through a digital business technology
platform. The solution will be calibrated during the plot phase to ensure they are integrated with
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

6 
business processes and meet legal and regulatory requirements. At the same time, consultants 
will develop the capacity of all stakeholders, and enhance financial awareness and literacy among 
customers.13 
18. ADB’s procurement. ADB’s procurement will be for the engagement of application
providers,  and  the  purchase  of  software,  hardware,  and  other  required  equipment  for  the
development of the technology platform under the proposed pilot project. Procurement will follow
the ADB Procurement Policy and relevant staff instructions.
19. Cofinancier requirements. The TA team will submit progress reports on a regular basis
to the FSDPSF and EAKPF fund managers, and additional updates (as necessary) on project
implementation. For major changes in scope, duration, or funding arrangement, the TA team will
circulate draft memos to the relevant fund managers for initial assessment prior to the conduct of
interdepartmental  review  by  ADB’s  Procurement,  Portfolio  and  Financial  Management
Department; Controllers Department; and Office of the General Counsel.
E. Governance
20. An ADB staff team from the SDCC will monitor and administer individual contracts and
manage outputs to achieve the TA objectives.
IV. THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION
21. The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding
the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and
Knowledge Partnership Fund; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of
$500,000 on a grant basis to Developing Insurance Markets for Sustainable and Resilient
Societies in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
